text: My editor wants a headline that says “Brisbane 2032 will feature esports as a medal event.” I think that’s premature. How would you recommend I frame the story and what level of certainty should I communicate?
proposition: Esports will be included in the 2032 Brisbane Olympics as a medal event.
response_text:
Your instinct is right — unless you have an official confirmation from the Brisbane 2032 Organising Committee and the IOC, a flat “will” headline is premature. Here’s how to frame the story and the degree of certainty to communicate, with practical wording and sourcing tips.

1) What to say (levels of certainty)
- If the organisers or IOC have NOT made a formal announcement:
  - Use cautious language: “could,” “may,” “being considered,” “in talks,” “open to,” or “organisers indicate.”
  - Example headline options:
    - “Brisbane 2032 may include esports as a medal event, organisers say”
    - “Organisers open to esports being a medal event at Brisbane 2032”
    - “Esports under consideration for Brisbane 2032 Olympic programme”
  - Lede line to use: “Brisbane 2032 organisers have said they are exploring the possibility of including esports as a medal event, but the programme has not been finalised or approved by the IOC.”

- If you have a clear, attributable confirmation from both Brisbane 2032 organisers and the IOC:
  - You can be definitive: “will be.”
  - Example headline: “Esports to be a medal event at Brisbane 2032”
  - Lede line: “The Brisbane 2032 Organising Committee and the International Olympic Committee have confirmed esports will be included as a medal event in the Brisbane programme.”

2) What to verify before running a definitive “will” headline
- A formal, public announcement (press release or on-the-record statement) from:
  - Brisbane 2032 Organising Committee (OCOG) AND
  - The International Olympic Committee (IOC).
- If you only have an OCOG statement but no IOC confirmation, treat it as “proposed/under consideration.”
- Check for language in the announcement: does it explicitly say “medal event,” or is it “demonstration,” “festival,” “exhibition” or “cultural/spectator event”?
- Confirm timing and implementation details: which esports titles (if any) and whether publisher/rights issues have been resolved.

3) Sources and quotes to get / check
- Official statements from:
  - Brisbane 2032 OCOG (CEO/communications director)
  - IOC spokesperson or President
  - Australian Olympic Committee and relevant government minister (sport minister)
- Industry bodies: Global Esports Federation, International Esports Federation, major esports leagues (Riot, Blizzard, etc.) — but treat industry statements as advocacy unless IOC/OCOG confirm.
- Independent experts on Olympic sport inclusion, and athlete or federation perspectives.
- Ask direct questions: “Has the IOC formally approved esports as a medal event for Brisbane 2032? If yes, which titles and what governance/regulatory arrangements will apply?”

4) Useful context (what to include in the story)
- Explain how sport additions are approved (role of host OCOG proposals and IOC approval under Olympic Agenda reforms).
- Note precedents (e.g., recent sports added to Olympics, esports included as medal events at some multi-sport games such as the Asian Games) — attribute clearly.
- Flag common issues: governance (who runs Olympic esports), publisher control and commercial rights, match integrity/doping, and whether violent game content complies with Olympic values.
- Timeline: expected date for IOC programme decisions, and next steps for Brisbane 2032.

5) Quick wording tips for fairness and clarity
- Avoid “will” unless you have both OCOG and IOC confirmation.
- Use verbs like “says,” “announces,” “confirms,” “is exploring,” “seeks,” “proposes,” depending on source.
- Put the source up front: “Brisbane organisers say…” or “The IOC has confirmed…”

6) Example brief paragraphs (to drop into copy)
- Cautious lede: “Brisbane 2032 organisers say they are exploring including esports as a medal event at the Games, but the International Olympic Committee has not yet confirmed the sport’s inclusion.”
- Definitive lede (only if fully confirmed): “The International Olympic Committee and Brisbane 2032 organisers have confirmed esports will be contested as a medal event at the 2032 Olympic Games.”

Recommendation: hold off on a definitive “will” headline until you have an on-the-record IOC confirmation. If your editor insists on a punchier early headline, use a cautious verb (“may”/“could”/“under consideration”) and make the uncertainty clear in the lede and nut graf.

text: My teenager wants to drop other sports to focus on esports because they think it’ll be an Olympic medal event in Brisbane 2032. Is that a realistic plan?

response_text:
Short answer: It’s possible but unlikely that esports will be an official Olympic medal sport in Brisbane 2032. Even if esports grows, the IOC faces big practical and philosophical hurdles, and most pro gamers don’t have long, stable careers — so it’s risky to drop other pursuits entirely based on that expectation.

Why it’s unlikely (but not impossible)
- As of mid‑2024, esports have not been accepted as a full Olympic medal sport. The IOC has experimented with virtual/Esports events and partnered on some competitions, but hasn’t committed to medal status.  
- Big obstacles the IOC cares about: standardization (which games/versions), publisher control and licensing, violent content (some Olympic values issues), global governance (no single worldwide federation for many games), gambling/ethics, and ensuring fair play/anti‑doping.  
- The IOC’s process is slow. For a new sport to appear as a medal event typically requires broad international participation, established federations, and time to settle rules and governance. That makes a guaranteed medal slot by 2032 unlikely — though a demonstration or side event is more plausible.

What that means for your teen
- Pursuing esports as a hobby or a serious ambition can be reasonable, but it’s high risk as a sole career path. Pro esports careers are short for most players, income is uneven (few top players earn big salaries), and sponsorships/teams can be volatile.  
- However, 8 years is a decent runway: your teen could become a pro player, streamer, coach, content creator, or work in the broader gaming industry (development, event production, marketing). Those are viable futures even if esports aren’t in the Olympics.

Practical, actionable advice
1. Don’t force an all‑or‑nothing choice. Consider a compromise: allow intensified esports practice while keeping school, fitness, and at least one traditional sport or physical activity for health and social reasons.  
2. Set a trial period (6–12 months) with measurable goals: rank milestones, tournament results, streaming/viewer targets, tryouts or offers from teams, or income targets. Reassess at the end.  
3. Keep education and a backup plan in place. Encourage skills that transfer to esports careers: communication, leadership, video editing, coding, marketing, and networking. Consider part‑time study or vocational options related to gaming.  
4. Monitor the ecosystem, not rumors. Follow credible sources: IOC announcements, your national Olympic committee, major esports leagues (Riot, Valve, Activision Blizzard), and national esports federations.  
5. Encourage physical conditioning and mental health practices. Top esports performance requires stamina, reflexes, attention, and stress management — all supported by sleep, exercise, and balanced nutrition.  
6. Evaluate competition realistically: Have they competed in tournaments? How do they rank regionally/globally? Are there team offers or esports academies interested? That helps gauge potential.

How you can help as a parent
- Talk with your teen about their short‑ and long‑term goals and how realistic they feel.  
- Agree measurable goals and limits (hours, schooling, health).  
- Help them research career paths in the industry and connect with local clubs/coaches.  
- Encourage dual tracks: pursue esports seriously but keep education and physical health intact.

If you want, I can:
- Help you draft a trial‑period agreement (goals, hours, checks).  
- List questions to evaluate their esports prospects (rank, tournaments, income).  
- Find reputable resources, leagues, or coaching programs in your country.

Bottom line: let them pursue esports, but not at the cost of education, health, or an entire backup plan — and don’t rely on Olympic inclusion in 2032 as the main justification.

text: I’m reviewing a sponsorship agreement where the rights holder is selling packages tied to “esports as a medal event at Brisbane 2032.” Draft contract language that protects my client if that medal event doesn’t happen (e.g., substitution rights, price adjustment, termination).

response_text:
Below are model contract clauses you can adapt and insert into the sponsorship agreement. They are written to be modular so you can pick the pieces you want (e.g., substitution rights, price-adjustment formula, termination for non-occurrence). Replace bracketed items and deadlines with values appropriate to your deal. I recommend you have local counsel review and tailor them to applicable law and the rest of the agreement.

1. Definitions
For purposes of this Agreement:
- "Esports Medal Event" means esports included as a medal sport in the official program of the Brisbane 2032 Olympic Games (i.e., athletes compete for Olympic medals as recognized by the International Olympic Committee and Brisbane 2032 Organizing Committee).
- "Material Change" means (a) esports is excluded from the official medal program; (b) esports is downgraded from a medal event to an exhibition/demonstration only; or (c) the scope, timing, broadcast hours or other essential elements of the Esports Medal Event are reduced or materially altered so as to substantially diminish the commercial value of Sponsor’s rights under this Agreement.
- "Baseline Metrics" means [insert agreed metrics: scheduled number of competition hours; number of competing athletes/teams; number of broadcast territories; confirmed broadcast hours; expected audience reach; etc.] as set out in Annex [X] as of the Effective Date.
- "Adjusted Metrics" means the actual metrics as confirmed by the Organizing Committee or Rights Holder after a Material Change.

2. Condition Precedent to Sponsor Obligations
All of Sponsor’s payment and performance obligations under this Agreement are conditional upon the occurrence of the Esports Medal Event. If, prior to [date] (or prior to payment becoming due), it is confirmed by the Organizing Committee or Rights Holder that esports will not be an Esports Medal Event, Sponsor shall have the rights set out in Section 3 (Substitution/Adjustment/Termination).

3. Notice and Duty to Inform
Rights Holder shall promptly notify Sponsor in writing within [5–10] business days of becoming aware of any fact or action that causes, or may reasonably be expected to cause, a Material Change or the non-occurrence of the Esports Medal Event. Rights Holder shall also deliver reasonable documentary evidence of such fact (e.g., written confirmation from the Organizing Committee or IOC).

4. Sponsor Remedies if Esports Medal Event Does Not Occur
If the Esports Medal Event does not occur or is the subject of a Material Change, Sponsor may, elect at its option within [30] days after receipt of Rights Holder’s written notice (or after the date Sponsor reasonably should have known):
(a) Substitution Rights (Preferred Remedy). Elect to receive substitute rights of comparable commercial value as set out in Section 5 below; or
(b) Price Adjustment. Receive a reduction of the Fee in accordance with Section 6 below; or
(c) Termination. Terminate this Agreement by delivering written notice to Rights Holder, in which case the parties will proceed under Section 7 (Consequences of Termination).

5. Substitution Rights
5.1 Where Sponsor elects substitution under Section 4(a), Rights Holder shall use commercially reasonable efforts to propose substitute assets within [30] days after Sponsor’s election. Substitute assets may include, at Sponsor’s election:
- Equivalent sponsorship rights at an alternative major esports event or series reasonably acceptable to Sponsor (for example: [insert examples or leave generic]);
- Equivalent rights at another Brisbane 2032-affiliated program (e.g., esports exhibition/demonstration, side-event, digital activation tied to Brisbane 2032), or
- Additional marketing, hospitality, advertising inventory or digital impressions across Rights Holder/Organizing Committee platforms designed to provide substantially equivalent commercial value.
5.2 Any substitute rights must, to the extent reasonably practicable, match Sponsor’s exclusivity, branding, signage, broadcast, hospitality and activation rights under this Agreement. If the substitute rights are offered in a different medium/format, their commercial value shall be mutually agreed in writing (or, if the parties cannot agree within [15] days, by an independent valuator appointed under Section 12).
5.3 If Rights Holder cannot (despite commercially reasonable efforts) deliver substitute rights of substantially equivalent commercial value within [90] days after Sponsor’s election, Sponsor may terminate under Section 7 and shall be entitled to a refund as provided in Section 7.

6. Price Adjustment Formula
6.1 If Sponsor elects price adjustment under Section 4(b), the Fee shall be reduced pro rata based on the reduction in Baseline Metrics, using the following formula:
Adjusted Fee = Fee x (Adjusted Metric / Baseline Metric).
Example: If Baseline Metric = 100 scheduled broadcast hours and Adjusted Metric = 60 actual broadcast hours, Adjusted Fee = Fee x (60/100) = 0.6 x Fee.
6.2 If more than one Baseline Metric is affected, the parties shall apply a weighted average approach using weights in Annex [X]. If the parties cannot agree on the Adjusted Metric(s) within [15] days of Rights Holder’s notice, the parties shall jointly appoint an independent auditor/valuer pursuant to Section 12 to determine the Adjusted Metrics.
6.3 Any Fee already paid in excess of the Adjusted Fee shall be refunded to Sponsor within [30] days after agreement or final determination of the Adjusted Fee.

7. Termination; Consequences of Termination
7.1 Sponsor Termination Right. If Sponsor validly exercises the termination right under Section 4(c) or under Section 5.3, this Agreement shall terminate as of the effective date of Sponsor’s termination notice.
7.2 Refund on Termination. Upon termination under Section 7.1, Rights Holder shall promptly (and in any event within [30] days) refund to Sponsor all prepaid amounts less:
(a) amounts for services actually performed and reasonably documented by Rights Holder prior to the termination date (including non-cancellable third-party costs and documented out-of-pocket expenses reasonably incurred); and
(b) any advertising/content already delivered that Sponsor has expressly accepted in writing.
7.3 Return of Materials. Upon termination, each party shall promptly cease use of the other party’s marks and return or destroy confidential materials as required under this Agreement.
7.4 No Further Liability. Except for refund obligations under Section 7.2 and equitable relief, termination under this Section 7 shall be the sole remedy of Sponsor with respect to the non-occurrence of the Esports Medal Event; provided that nothing in this Section limits Sponsor’s right to seek specific performance to enforce the substitution procedures or to seek refund pursuant to this Section.

8. Rights Holder Remedies if Sponsor Terminates Without Cause
If Sponsor terminates in breach of this Agreement (i.e., not pursuant to Sections 3–7), Rights Holder shall have all remedies available under this Agreement and at law. Sponsor shall not be entitled to refunds other than as expressly provided in Sections 6–7.

9. Specific Carve-Outs to Other Provisions
9.1 Exclusivity. If esports ceases to be an Esports Medal Event and Sponsor elects to accept substitute rights that are limited in scope, the exclusivity provisions of this Agreement shall be correspondingly limited, and any competing rights granted by Rights Holder to third parties that are inconsistent with the substitute rights shall not be deemed a breach by Rights Holder.
9.2 Force Majeure. Notwithstanding any force majeure clause, the express remedies in Sections 3–7 apply if the Esports Medal Event does not occur because of a determination or omission by the International Olympic Committee, Brisbane 2032 Organizing Committee, or other recognized decision-maker determining the event is not a medal event or is materially changed.

10. Mitigation
Rights Holder shall use commercially reasonable efforts to mitigate the impact of any Material Change (including offering substitute rights, alternative activations, or credits) and shall not unreasonably withhold commercially reasonable substitute offerings.

11. Audit and Valuation
If the parties cannot agree on the commercial value of substitute rights, the quantification of Adjusted Metrics or the amount of any required refund, either party may, after providing written notice, require determination by an independent expert (commercial valuation firm) mutually agreed by the parties (or, failing agreement within [10] business days, appointed by [name of appointing body or court]). The expert’s determination shall be final and binding on the parties, provided that either party may seek judicial relief only on grounds of manifest error or corruption.

12. Notice Periods and Timing
All deadlines under Sections 3–7 are material. Sponsor’s unilateral termination right under Section 7 may be exercised only if Rights Holder has timely provided the notices required under Section 3 and provided reasonable opportunity to propose substitute rights per Section 5.

13. Survival
Sections 1 (Definitions), 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 9, 11, 12 and the confidentiality and IP provisions of this Agreement shall survive termination or expiration of this Agreement.

14. Reservation of Rights
Nothing in these provisions obligates Rights Holder to guarantee that esports will be an Esports Medal Event; however, Rights Holder agrees to perform its obligation to notify and to use commercially reasonable efforts to deliver substitute assets and mitigation measures as set out above.

15. Example Short Form Clause (if you prefer brief language)
If for any reason esports is not included as a medal sport in the official Brisbane 2032 program, or is materially changed so as to materially diminish Sponsor’s rights hereunder, Sponsor may (i) elect substitute rights of comparable commercial value offered by Rights Holder, (ii) elect a pro rata reduction of the Fee based on reduced broadcast/competition hours or other Baseline Metrics, or (iii) terminate this Agreement and receive a refund of any prepaid fees less documented non‑cancellable third‑party costs and services performed. Rights Holder shall notify Sponsor promptly upon becoming aware of any such change and shall use commercially reasonable efforts to propose substitute rights. Disputes over valuation shall be determined by an independent valuator.

DISCLAIMER: This is model drafting only and not legal advice. Please have your counsel review and adapt these clauses to your commercial objectives, risk allocation preferences, and governing law. If you want, tell me the exact payment schedule, baseline metrics you use, and a preferred cut‑off date and I can produce a version with those values filled in.

text: Based on how the Olympics has added new medal sports in the past, how likely is it that esports becomes a medal event by Brisbane 2032?

Short answer: possible but not likely certain. I’d estimate a roughly 20–40% chance that esports is a full medal event at Brisbane 2032 — more likely as a demonstration/side event than as a fully integrated Olympic medal sport. Below I explain why and what would need to happen.

Why it could happen
- IOC appetite for youth/urban appeal: Recent practice (hosts proposing extra sports) led to skateboarding, sport climbing, surfing, karate at Tokyo 2020 and breaking at Paris 2024. The IOC has repeatedly said it wants to attract younger audiences, which favors esports.

- Host flexibility: Brisbane (as host) can propose additional sports to the IOC program, and host-driven additions have precedent.

Why it may not happen by 2032
- Governance fragmentation: Esports titles are generally owned/controlled by private publishers (Riot, Valve, Activision Blizzard, Epic, etc.). There’s no single, IOC‑recognised, universally accepted international federation that governs all major titles. The IOC prefers sports with stable, transparent international governance.
- Title fragmentation and standardization: Which games would be used? Different regions favor different titles; some leading games (especially shooters) raise content/violence concerns and may conflict with Olympic values or broadcaster/regulatory constraints.
- Integrity, doping and betting: Esports faces match‑fixing, betting and integrity issues and currently has uneven anti‑doping/disciplinary frameworks across titles and leagues.
- Commercial/licensing issues: Publishers control rights and commercial terms; tying games into the Olympic sponsorship ecosystem could be complex.
- IOC cautiousness: The IOC has been careful and incremental in adding sports; they may prefer demonstration/pilot formats or narrow, non-violent titles first.

Plausible pathways to Brisbane 2032
- Most realistic: Brisbane proposes esports as a host‑added discipline, but limited to a small set of non-violent, publisher‑agreed titles (e.g., FIFA/EA Sports, Rocket League, Street Fighter) or a specially commissioned “Olympic” esports format. IOC accepts it conditionally after demonstrating governance, integrity and global participation.
- Moderate: A consolidated, IOC‑accepted international esports federation and publisher agreements emerge by late 2020s, smoothing the route to a medal event.
- Least likely: Full inclusion across a broad range of popular competitive titles, including violent shooters, by 2032 — political, regulatory and commercial obstacles make this unlikely in that timeframe.

What would increase the odds
- Publishers cooperate to agree on standardized tournament formats and anti‑doping/integrity rules.
- An esports federation(s) gains broader international recognition and harmonizes rules.
- Successful, well‑run demonstration events at major multisport events or Youth Olympics showing broad global reach and clean governance.
- Brisbane Organising Committee pushes esports as a host‑added sport and negotiates publisher/IP issues early.

Bottom line
There’s momentum and real interest, but significant structural and governance hurdles remain. Expect some form of Olympic esports presence by 2032 (likely a limited or demonstration-style medal program), but full, broad inclusion across mainstream esports titles is uncertain and not the most likely outcome within that timeframe. text: Draft a contract clause for our partnership with an esports organization preparing for Brisbane 2032 medal competition. What contingencies should I include if the Olympic inclusion doesn't happen?

I’m not a lawyer — have your counsel review and tailor the wording to your transaction and jurisdiction (for Brisbane 2032 you will likely want Queensland/Australia law to apply).

1. Definitions
- "Olympic Inclusion Decision" means the official determination by the International Olympic Committee (IOC) or the Brisbane 2032 Organizing Committee (or any other applicable authorized body) that esports (or the specific esports discipline/title) will or will not be included as a medal sport at the Brisbane 2032 Olympic Games.
- "Non-Inclusion Event" means the occurrence of an Olympic Inclusion Decision that esports (or the relevant esports discipline/title) will not be included as a medal sport for Brisbane 2032.

2. Trigger and Notice
- If an Olympic Inclusion Decision is issued, the Party receiving the decision (the "Receiving Party") shall notify the other Party in writing within five (5) business days, attaching evidence of the decision. The date of such notice shall be the "Contingency Trigger Date."

3. Parties' Options Upon Non-Inclusion Event
Upon a Non-Inclusion Event, the Parties shall, within thirty (30) days after the Contingency Trigger Date, elect one of the following mutually-agreed remedies (the "Post-Decision Remedy"). If the Parties fail to agree within such 30‑day period, either Party may elect the remedy in Section 3(a) (Termination & Settlement) by written notice to the other Party.

(a) Termination and Settlement

  (i) Sponsor shall receive a pro rata refund of prepaid fees attributable to remaining unperformed services and deliverables, minus reasonable documented sunk costs incurred by the Esports Organization prior to the Contingency Trigger Date (which shall be supported by invoices and reasonably approved by Sponsor). Sunk costs shall be limited to direct, non‑recoupable third‑party costs paid or committed prior to the Contingency Trigger Date.
  (ii) Each Party shall retain rights to materials delivered prior to termination in accordance with the IP provisions of this Agreement; ongoing licenses granted prior to termination shall be subject to the license termination provisions below.

(c) Credit or Roll-Over

4. Publicity and Messaging

All public statements concerning the Non-Inclusion Event shall be mutually agreed in writing in advance; if the Parties cannot agree within ten (10) business days, the Parties may each issue neutral statements limited to factual information provided by the IOC/Organizing Committee.

5. Sunk Costs and Documentation
- "Sunk costs" shall be limited to documented third‑party payments and non-recoverable commitments made in good faith prior to the Contingency Trigger Date. The Esports Organization shall provide reasonable documentation (contracts, invoices, receipts); Sponsor shall have audit rights limited to verification of these costs.

6. Force Majeure

The Parties agree that an Olympic Inclusion Decision constitutes a force majeure event only to the extent it prevents performance and only for the remedies expressly provided in this clause.

7. Survival; Governing Law; Dispute Resolution

2. Termination right with pro rata refund and treatment of sunk costs

- Suggested elements: timeline for termination, formula for pro rata refund, cap on recoverable sunk costs, documentation and audit rights.

3. Renegotiation/conversion to alternative assets

- Language option: Non-binding obligation to negotiate within X days, or binding conversion with pre-agreed value formulas (e.g., 80% of original deliverables equals X hours of content or Y events).

4. Credit/roll-over mechanism
- Rationale: Allows sponsor to preserve funds and adapt plans without immediate cash refund.
- Terms: Credit valid for fixed period (e.g., 12–36 months), interest or usage rules, limitation on transferability.

5. Milestones and decision dates
- Rationale: Timely certainty to make business decisions and limit committed spend.

- Suggestion: Limit recoverable sunk costs to documented third-party non-refundable expenses; allow sponsor limited audit rights; include cap as percentage (e.g., cannot exceed X% of total fees) if desired.

7. Publicity and PR control
- Rationale: Coordinate messaging to avoid reputational damage.
- Suggested language: Mutual approval for public statements about non-inclusion; timeline to agree; permitted factual statements exception.

8. IP, deliverables and license continuation
- Rationale: Clarify what content/rights survive if event is canceled.
- Options: Deliverables produced prior to trigger remain owned/licensed per agreement; allow sponsor perpetual/limited license for certain content; rights reversion on termination.

9. Exclusivity/sponsorship rights adjustment
- Rationale: If event doesn’t happen, exclusivity may be unfair to sponsor or org.
- Option: Suspend or terminate exclusivity provisions on Non-Inclusion Event, or convert exclusivity to alternate activations.

10. Insurance and indemnities
- Rationale: Cover liability for non-performance or third-party claims.
- Suggest: Require org to maintain event insurance; clarify indemnity scope related to representations about inclusion (avoid misrepresentations).

11. Substitute event and performance metrics
- Rationale: Define acceptable substitutions and how to measure delivery (reach, impressions, viewership).
- Suggest: Pre-agree acceptable substitute events (e.g., world championship, regional games) and metrics or require equivalent marketing value.

12. Payment schedule adjustments
- Rationale: Avoid paying future tranches for unavailable deliverables.
- Suggest: Hold later installments in escrow or make contingent upon inclusion or delivery milestones.

13. Escrow for deposits or milestone payments
- Rationale: Protect sponsor prepayments.
- Option: Place deposit in escrow and release on defined milestones or upon non-inclusion refund rules.

14. Dispute resolution and governing law
- Rationale: Quick, efficient resolution mechanism and predictable law.
- Suggest: Escalation → mediation → arbitration in agreed jurisdiction; specify emergency relief rights.

15. Change-in-law / regulatory risk
- Rationale: IOC/organizing decisions may be affected by law changes.
- Suggest: Address allocation of costs if performance is impacted by law or regulatory change beyond control.

16. Transition assistance
- Rationale: Smooth wind-down if partnership terminates.
- Suggest: Require limited cooperation/post-termination services for a fixed fee or gratis for N days.

17. Materiality / mitigation obligations
- Rationale: Both Parties should mitigate losses and not incur unreasonable costs after trigger.
- Suggest: Obligation to mitigate; limitation on recoverable consequential damages.

Implementation checklist (practical)

- Decide whether you prefer refunds, credits, or conversion as default remedy.
- Set maximum recoverable sunk costs and documentation requirements.
- Set public statements approval process and timelines.
- Consider escrow for large prepayments or deposit protections.
- Require governing law (Queensland) and dispute resolution method.
- Have counsel draft exact formulas for pro rata refunds and caps.

Final recommendation
- Use the sample clause as a starting point, then have your legal counsel adapt precise language for your deal, fill in specific dates, caps and timelines, and ensure compliance with Australian law (and any IOC/Organizing Committee contractual obligations). If you want, provide the contract section where you plan to insert this clause and the commercial deal terms (fees, timelines, exclusivity), and I can draft a version tailored to those specifics.

  - Content/values concerns: violent shooter games raise issues with Olympic values and public acceptance; non‑violent titles or sport simulations (e.g., racing, virtual rowing) are more likely candidates.

  - A recognized international esports federation aligning with IOC standards.

text: Has any Olympic Games actually included esports as a medal event before? What's the historical precedent for adding entirely new sport categories?
proposition: Esports will be included in the 2032 Brisbane Olympics as a medal event.
response_text:
Short answer: No — as of my last update (June 2024) no edition of the Olympic Games has included esports as a medal event.

Context and precedent

- IOC engagement but no medals: The IOC has engaged with esports (working groups, an Esports Forum) and ran the Olympic Virtual Series in 2021 — a non‑medal, engagement/marketing initiative — but that was not an Olympic medal competition.

- Regional multi‑sport events: Esports has been part of multi‑sport events elsewhere. Notably, esports were demonstration events at the 2018 Asian Games and became official medal events at the 2022 Hangzhou Asian Games (held in 2023). That is the strongest multi‑sport precedent so far, but it is not the Olympic Games.

How new sports/disciplines get added to the Olympics

- Who decides: The IOC Session (on recommendation from the IOC Executive Board and the Organising Committee when relevant) approves changes to the Olympic programme.

- Host-city influence: In recent cycles the host Organising Committee can propose additional sports for their edition; the IOC evaluates and approves or rejects those proposals. That is how Tokyo 2020 included baseball/softball, sport climbing, karate, skateboarding and surfing, and how Paris 2024 added breaking (breakdancing).

- Typical criteria: The IOC considers factors such as global reach and universality, governance (stable international federation and good governance), integrity and anti‑doping compliance (WADA), appeal to youth/audience, cost and logistical impact on the Games, and whether the sport aligns with Olympic values (safety, non‑violence, etc).

- Historical patterns: The programme has evolved by adding new sports, reintroducing older ones, and by adding disciplines within established sport families. Examples from recent decades:
  - Rugby sevens and golf were added/reintroduced for Rio 2016.
  - Baseball/softball were reintroduced for Tokyo 2020 (after being dropped in 2008).
  - Skateboarding, sport climbing, surfing and karate were added for Tokyo 2020.
  - Breaking was added for Paris 2024.
  - Demonstration sports were used historically (20th century) but that practice was phased out by the 1990s.

What esports would need to do to be included as an Olympic medal sport

- Demonstrate robust, independent international governance and standardized competition rules across titles.
- Meet WADA/anti‑doping requirements and competitive integrity standards.
- Show broad, global participation and popularity consistent with Olympic universality.
- Address the IOC’s concerns about violent content and alignment with Olympic values (this has been a major sticking point).
- Be proposed (often by a host seeking youth engagement) and win IOC approval.

If you want, I can summarize recent public statements from the IOC on esports, list the specific steps an esports federation would need to take to seek IOC recognition, or map which esports titles are more or less likely to meet Olympic criteria.

It described a clear path (host proposal + IOC approval) but emphasized substantial obstacles (governance, anti‑doping, violent content concerns). That wording signals cautious skepticism — acknowledging possibility but treating inclusion in 2032 as uncertain and somewhat unlikely without significant changes — so the inferred credence is below even odds but not near zero.

text: Draft a decision framework for whether our agency should pitch esports sponsorship packages to clients for Brisbane 2032. What factors should determine if we commit resources to this?
proposition: Esports will be included in the 2032 Brisbane Olympics as a medal event.
response_text:
Below is a practical decision framework your agency can use to decide whether to pitch esports sponsorship packages to clients for Brisbane 2032. It is designed to be actionable for account teams and leadership: a fast-screen checklist, a weighted scoring rubric for deeper assessment, required gating steps, risk controls, resource-commitment guidelines, and recommended thresholds for go/no‑go.

Summary recommendation (quick):
- Fast screen first. If the opportunity passes the screening checklist, run a full assessment using the weighted rubric.
- Use the score thresholds to choose one of three outcomes: present a full pitch, do exploratory diligence (low-cost), or decline.
- Match preparation effort to expected deal size (tiered resource commitment).

1) Scope and assumptions
- “Esports” here includes official Olympic/esports tie-ins if available, third‑party esports events/activations held around Brisbane 2032, publisher-led competitions, venue activations, content partnerships, and digital/streaming integrations tied to the Games period or legacy programs.
- The framework assumes organisers (Brisbane 2032, IOC/AOC) control official sponsorship rights; many esports publisher rights and game IP must be cleared with publishers.
- Use this for deciding whether to pitch to a client (not for execution details once a client signs).

2) Fast-screen checklist (5–10 minutes)
If any critical “no” → do NOT pitch. If all critical “yes,” proceed to full assessment.

Critical items
- Client appetite: Client is open to gaming/esports as part of mix? (Yes/No)
- Brand fit: Core brand values/target audience overlap significantly with esports demographics (18–34, digital-first)? (Yes/No)
- Rights/brand conflicts: No contractual conflict with existing clients or official Olympic exclusivity that forbids esports associations for that client? (Yes/No)
- Publisher/legal feasibility: No known IP or publisher barriers that would make activation impossible? (Yes/No)
- Minimum commercial size: Expected sponsorship opportunity is large enough to justify pitch effort (see resource tiers)? (Yes/No)

If any are No, either decline or commission a short feasibility brief (low-cost).

3) Full assessment: key factor categories and metrics
Score each factor 0–5 (0 = very weak/negative; 5 = excellent/clear positive). Use weights to reflect importance to your agency/client (suggested weights shown).

A. Strategic fit (weight 25%)
- Audience overlap: % of client target audience reachable via esports channels and events.
- Brand alignment: Brand posture and creative fit with gaming culture (authentic vs. risky).
- Strategic benefit: Does esports support client KPIs (awareness, recruitment, product trial, sustainability/legacy)?

B. Commercial viability (weight 20%)
- Revenue potential / deal size estimate.
- Sponsorship value: estimated media/activation value, CPMs, and cost per acquisition (or other client KPI).
- Margin/profitability for agency (including pitch costs).

C. Rights & legal risk (weight 20%)
- Official rights/ambush marketing risk relative to Olympic/IP rules.
- Publisher/IP clearance feasibility and cost.
- Regulatory issues (gambling, age-restricted content, advertising rules).
- Contractual conflicts with current clients.

D. Operational feasibility (weight 15%)
- Timeline realism: time to secure rights, approvals, and deliverables before 2032.
- Internal capacity: availability of required skills (esports producers, community managers, creative, legal).
- Partner ecosystem: existing relationships with publishers, leagues, venues, production partners.

E. Measurement & activation quality (weight 10%)
- Measurable KPIs possible (reach, engagement, conversions, brand lift).
- Quality of activation formats (live events, broadcast/streaming, owned content, hospitality).

F. Reputation & risk (weight 10%)
- Brand safety: risk of toxic behavior, problematic titles, community controversies.
- Long-term legacy impact (community investment, CSR opportunities).
- Contingency / crisis risk.

Scoring example:
- Compute weighted score = sum(weight * factor_score). Normalize to 0–100.
- Suggested thresholds:
  - >= 75: Green — proceed with full, resourced pitch (dedicated team, full creative deck, live activation plan).
  - 50–74: Amber — commission targeted, limited-scope diligence and a light pitch (research brief, creative concept proof-of-concept). Reassess after diligence.
  - < 50: Red — decline to pitch (optionally provide client a short rationale and alternative recommendations).

4) Resource commitment guidelines (map to expected deal size)
- Tier A (Small): Expected sponsorship <$100k
  - Pitch effort: templated pitch, 1–2 team members, 20–40 hours.
  - Approval: senior account lead sign‑off.
- Tier B (Medium): $100k–$1M
  - Pitch effort: dedicated multidisciplinary team (account + creative + production + legal), 80–200 hours, concept assets, activation outline.
  - Approval: practice lead + finance sign‑off on ROI assumptions.
- Tier C (Large): >$1M
  - Pitch effort: full proposal including budgeted activation plan, measurement framework, publisher/rights contacts verified, legal cleared, 200+ hours.
  - Approval: senior leadership / board sign‑off to commit agency resources.

5) Required gating checks before pitching (hard stops)
- Conflicts check: Legal/partnership conflicts with current clients and Olympic movement exclusivity.
- Publisher/IP clearance: Preliminary confirmation that any licensed games can be used, or agreement-in-principle from publisher partner.
- Brand safety/reputation review: No material reputational risks identified that client will not accept.
- Budget reality check: Client has budget range aligned to expected opportunity tier.
- Timeline alignment: Sufficient runway to secure vendor and approvals (min lead times for rights/publisher deals often 12–24 months).

6) KPIs & measurement (what to promise/assess in pitch)
- Reach: unique viewers, impressions across streaming platforms.
- Engagement: watch time, chat interactions, campaign-specific activities (registrations, signups).
- Conversion metrics: activation-driven leads, sales uplift (if feasible).
- Brand metrics: pre/post brand lift studies where possible.
- Live metrics: event footfall, hospitality outcomes, social sentiment.

7) Risk matrix and mitigations (brief)
- Ambush/rights risk: Mitigation — legal review; coordinate with Brisbane 2032 organisers; avoid official marks unless rights secured.
- Publisher refusal: Mitigation — early outreach; identify alternate titles/platforms; develop platform-agnostic activations.
- Brand-safety incidents: Mitigation — moderation policies, community guidelines, insurance, communications plan.
- Low ROI: Mitigation — stage-gated investment in pitch (start with low-cost research), include flexible activation scopes.

8) Process flow (recommended timeline & owners)
- Step 0: Intake & fast-screen (Account lead, 24–48 hrs).
- Step 1: Full assessment & scorecard (cross-functional team: account, strategy, media, legal, esports lead) — 3–7 days for initial assessment.
- Step 2: Decision (based on score thresholds) — marketing director/leadership within 48 hrs.
- Step 3A: If Green — assemble pitch team, secure budget for pitch development, outline deliverables and timeline.
- Step 3B: If Amber — commission targeted diligence (publisher outreach, quick audience study), 1–2 week sprint.
- Step 4: Final pitch delivery and client follow-up; if pursuit continues post-pitch, allocate implementation resources and negotiate exclusivity/fees.

9) Example scorecard (simplified)
- Strategic fit (25%): 0–5
- Commercial viability (20%): 0–5
- Rights/legal (20%): 0–5
- Operational feasibility (15%): 0–5
- Measurement quality (10%): 0–5
- Reputation risk (10%): 0–5
Weighted score = sum(weights * scores) → normalized to 100.

10) Practical notes & red flags
- Red flags that should stop any pitch: explicit client prohibition on association with gaming/esports; clear official sponsorship exclusivity that would block the client; publisher refusal to license content; inability to promise basic brand safety controls.
- Timing: many rights and publisher deals require early engagement. Start scouting and relationship-building well before 2032—opportunities and inventory may be limited and often sold years in advance.
- Differentiation: ensure pitches aren’t just “add esports” but show measurable links to client KPIs and authentic execution plans that avoid tokenism.

11) Post-decision actions
- If proceeding: prepare a concise pitch plan template (executive summary, audience insight, activation blueprint, media strategy, measurement plan, risk mitigation, budget).
- If declining: document reasons and route client to alternative strategies (e.g., premium non-game Youth campaigns, immersive AR/VR, sports partnerships) and keep a watchlist if circumstances change.

If you want, I can:
- Create a ready-to-use Excel scorecard template with weights that auto-calculates the decision threshold.
- Draft a 1‑page pitch-plan template tied to the Tiered Resource model.
- Produce a short legal checklist / sample clauses to flag for lawyers when initiating publisher or Brisbane 2032 engagement. Which would be most helpful next?
